div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £ 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice every Wednesday at about S.S. a.m. in time for the Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice at 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival at Trieste every Wednesday at about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reaching London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and Luggage-Van attached every Saturday to the Express Train leaving Cairo at 9.30 a.m. and will be conveyed directly to the Quay alongside the steamer.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS, ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, MANSOURAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £1.500,000
Reserve Fund . . £500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: THE RISING IN THE FRENCH SUDAN.
div.p: "The Manchester Guardian" makes the following interesting comments on the trouble in the Sudan: The destruction of a French post in the Sudan makes it fairly certain that the British disaster near Sokoto was not an incident in any mere local rising. The nearest point on the French frontier is at least 150 miles distant from Sokoto, and though the boundary represents no racial division, a movement which affects French and English alike at points one or two hundred miles apart must be due to some widespread political discontent. A new Mahdi, it is said, has arisen in the Western Sudan. We hope that is not true; but the time, was fear, may be ripe for another movement like that which overthrew the Egyptian rule in the Sudan was an unmitigated curse, while the English and French in the Western Sudan have probably improved the well-being of the majority of their subjects. But the Egpytians, after all were Mahomedans, and the French and English are not. A second Mahdi might have to play on a different string from the first, but the tune might be just as terrible. Our political distinctions between the Egyptian Sudan, Nigeria, and the French Sudan correspond to no reality. The Sudan is best thought of as one vast country stretching from Sokoto on the west to Khartaum on the east, and from Kano on the south to Morocco, Algeria, and Tripoli on the north. There is constant communication over the whole of this vast district. Placards issued by the Mahdi who overthrew Egyptian rule in the Eastern Sudan were found posted in a street of Bida, two thousand miles west of Khartoum; and when Lord Kitchener began his reconquest of the Sudan, the Khalifa urged the Sultan of Sokoto to make a diversion in his favour by driving the Christians out of Nigeria. The pressure on this fanatical Mahomedan population in the Sudan has now for many years been kept up from several sides at once from the Egyptian Sudan on the east, from the Mediterranean downwards by France, and from the Gulf of Guinea upwards through Nigeria by England. Almost all the Mahomedan tribes have a common grievance, and if a counterstroke were attempted the only wonder would be that it had been delayed so long. The present movement may not turn out to be so serious, but, whether it is or not, a general rising of the Mahomedan tribes in the Sudan must always be accounted one of the permanent dangers to the Anglo-French settlement in North Africa. It would not be in the least fanciful to suspect some connection between the rising in Sokoto and the Conference of Algeciras.

div.head: BRITISH RULE IN CYPRUS.
div.p: The "Courrier European" publishes an article by M. S. Skiadaresis, giving an account of the condition of affairs in Cyprus. The writer asserts that British rule has not improved the economic condition of the island, but has, of anything, made it worse. He ascribes this failure, first, to the saddling of the island with the payment of the 93,000 per annum which England agreed to make over to Turkey by the Treaty of June 4th, 1878; second, to the costly administration by high-salaried British officials; and, third, to the wasteful and sometimes (as in the case of the recent railway construction totally mistaken way of carrying out public works. The writer acknowledges that now, on account of this failure on the part of the British to improve matters, there in the island a widespread national feeling in favour of anuexation to Greece, and he expresses the hope that the new High Commissioner, Sir Charles King-Harman, to whom he gives every credit for his generosity and consideration in treating the natives, may yet plead the cause of the Cypriots before his Government.

div.head: Supreme Consular Court.
div.p: Judge Bettesworth Piggott has arrived in Cario on circuit, and stays at the Continental Hotel.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to March 1 amounted to 177,337 tons, as compared with 95,568 tons last year.

div.head: Found Drowned.
div.p: The body of an unknown man was found floating in the Mahmoudieh Canal yesterday. It was taken out and sent to the hospital.

div.head: Minicipal Commission.
div.p: It is probable that the first meeting of the Commission of the Alexandria Municipality after the elections will be on Wednesday week.

div.head: "The Nile Quest."
div.p: A new edition of Sir Harry Johnston's "The Nile Quest" will be issued next week in "The Story of Exploration" series edited by J. Scott Keltie, LL.D.

div.head: Yacht in Harbour.
div.p: The P. & O. staem yacht Vectis arrived at Alexandria this morning from Jaffa with 168 tourists on board who have proceeded to Cairo. The Vectis leaves again on Friday for Naples.

div.head: The New Quay Lands.
div.p: As soon as the evaluation committee of the Alexandria Municipality has finished its valuation of the property in the new quay a certain quantity of land will be put up for auction.

div.head: Egyptian Estates.
div.p: We learn on reliable authority that the above company have resold a portion of the building estate in Alexandria which they recently purchased from Mr. G. B. Alderson at a price which leaves the company a profit of over 120 percent on their original price.

div.head: Cotton in Cyprus.
div.p: The latest Bulletin of the Imperial Institute an account is given of a visit recently paid by the Director of the Imperial Institute to Cyprus at the instance of the Colonial Office to enquire into the possibility of cotton cultivation and the general agricultural resources of the island.

div.head: Concert.
div.p: Tomorrow evening Mr. and Miss Kazanti will give their second concert at the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria. We will publish the programme tomorrow. Tickets can be procured at the establishments of Messrs. Lifonti, Hakh, and Romanelli. The concert will begin at 9:15 p.m.

div.head: Alexandria Central Buildings Co.
div.p: We hear from London that the Anglo-Egyptian Bank has placed in London debentures of the Alexandria Central Buildings Company, Limited, to the value of £100,000 bearing interest at four per cent and redeemable in sixty years' time at the maximum or at any time prior to that date on receipt of notice one month in advance.

div.head: Bankruptcies.
div.p: The Mixed Commercial Court at Alexandria has declared the following persons bankrupt: Mohamed Akroa, Aly Abdel Guelil Cherif, Ahmed Mohamed, and G. Fracolo. Messrs. F. Raad & Co. and Mahmoud Hassan, and Mohamed Eclibe, who had been allowed to benefit by a "concordat preventif," have also been declared bankrupt as the Court refused to consider them as unfortunate and bona-fide debtors.

div.head: The Barbers' Strike.
div.p: On Saturday evening the whote of the master barbers of Alexandria with only three exceptions informed the men on strike that they would agree to accept the conditions demanded. Henceforth, therefore, the barbers' working day at Alexandria will be one of then and a half hours instead of twelve and a half, as before.
The three recalcitrant master barbers have been invited to attend at the Italian Consulate, where it is hoped that they will be induced to come into line with the other master barbers.

div.head: AN INCIDENT AT THE ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
div.p: The Algeciras correspondent of the Paris "Matin" reports that on Friday evening, whilst the German and Italian diplomats were engaged in an animated conversation, the German evidently displeased the Italian, who arose, turning his back on the German, and retired to his apartments.

div.head: BANKING DEVELOTMENTS
div.p: COMPTOIR D'ESCOMPTE

This morning, the inauguration of the headquarters in Egypt of the Comptoir Nationale d'Escompte de Paris" took place at the magnificent premises of the great French bank in the Palazzo Antoniadis at Alexandria.

Over a year ago the management at Paris decided, in view of the growing prosperity of Egpyt, to come here, and the old residence of the Antoniadis family was secured on a twenty years' lease, at a rental of £2,000 a year. Since then the building has been entirely transformed and a large part of the garden has been converted into a large and airy counting house.

The transformation of the building into a bank has been most successful from an architectural point of view, and the general effect is excellent. Extensive strong rooms have been constructed below the bank. At the entrance there is a luxurious reception room for the convenience of the clients and other visitors, whilst the first floor is devoted to the Accounts Department.

Mr. Llewelyn, the manager, is to be congratulated on having so successfully achieved the difficult task of converting a private residence into a bank. The contractors were Messrs. Degiarde Brothers and this local firm has done some excellent work in making the building suitable for a large financial establishment.
The headquarters of the Comptoir will be at Alexandria, but a branch is also to be opened at Cairo in a few months' time.

div.head: THE FITZNER QUARTETTE
div.p: The second and last concert of the season was given by this quartette at the New Khedivial Hotel on Thursday night before a large audience. While it would be presumption to attempt to pass judgement upon the performance, which was as perfect of its kind as anything we have ever heard, the programme did not perhaps fulfill all the expectations that a casual perusal of its contents might naturally arouse. The first time, quartette by Volkmann, in G minor was a very beautiful example of what absolute sympathy and unanimity will do in a string quartette, the performers indeed not only giving the impression of being of one mind, but it almost seemed as if their instruments were swayed by one hand. The andante movement of this piece, especially with its swelling cadences relieved by occasional plaintive touches, and passages of syncopation introduced so cleverly as to avoid all possibility of abruptness or too marked a contrast, was delightful, and one was left, when this piece terminated, with a strong hope that there were things as good or even better to come. It was to be regretted, however, that this piece should have been immediately followed by a characteristic but not very enlivening Andante funebro by Tachaikowsky. We do not care to be reminded of funerals on the rare occasions that we go forth to luxuriate in the embraces of the fickle muse, even through the medium of such a master in the expression of the tragic in musical art as this composer. His tragedy has perhaps too much pessimism and too little grandeur to be always very satisfying. But the music of its kind was beautiful and one could detect occasional faint reminiscences of the famous "Pathetique" which made one feel at home. An Allegro vivo of Dvorak's came as a somewhat welcome relief. We now pass to the 'Beethoven' in A minor, an impressive but rather unintelligible work in four movements, the third movement in which takes the form of on ode written to a divinity in gratitude for a cure. It contains a beautiful chorale, with the tonic F, but in strict accordance with the moda in which it is written; the B in the scale is natural, and this would account for the rather unexpected harmonies this piece contained, which sometimes left one in doubt as to what the composer was driving at. It is one of the very rare examples of a piece written strictly in accordance with this ancient musical mode. By special request, at the end of the performance, a quartette of Griegs was given, and in this the performers surpassed themselves. No composer seems to combine genuine melody with a solid background of grand and impressive harmonies and this composer does, and the piece sent one home with a feeling of gratitude for a fitting termination to what had proved a regular festa of musical enjoyment.

div.head:
FRONTIER DISPUTE.
THE NOUR EL BAHR.
div.p: DELEGATES' MYSTERIOUS DEPARTURE
(From OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Suez, Saturday.

The Coast Guard cruiser Nour el Bahr sailed from Suez yesterday morning for Akaba with Government stores and despatches for H.M.S. Diana, which is still anchored at Farson island to prevent the Turkish troops occupying it.
It is stated that at present the Turkish forces at Taba amount to about 5,000 men, with artillery.
It is quite certain that the first time the Nour el Bahr went to Akaba and sent out a boat with officers and men, the Turks refused to allow them to land, and ordered them to go back to the ship.
The Turkish delegates for the frontier dispute, Colonel Muzaffer Pacha and Bimbashi Fehmy, have left Cairo for, it is said, Bayrout. It is surmised that they will start thence for Ma'an.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Ibrahim Pasha Fathy, the Emir el Hag, has written to the Ministry of the Interior stating that he has agreed with the Sherif of Mecca and the Vali of the Hedjaz that the Holy Carpet should be conveyed from Mecca to Medina by the direct route; and that the camels needed for the pilgrims have been hired at the rate of L.E. 15 each, to travel from Mecca to Medina and thenpe to Yambo.
The Mahmal will arrive at Yambo on tha 20th inst., and the Khedivial Mail Line have been warned to prepare their steamers for the conveyance of the Egyptian pilgrims on that date.

div.head: THE HOHENZOLLERN.
div.p: Tbe Russian packet landed twenty-five of the Hohenzollern's passengers from Candia at Alexandria on Saturday afternoon. Among these passengers were Consul General von Hartmann and his family.

The remainder of the passengers, including the Archduke Joseph and the Archduchess Augusta of Austria will arrive from Candia at Alexandria by the North German Lloyd's S.S. Schleswig at daybreak tomorrow.

div.head: PHENOMENON SEEN AT LUXOR.
div.p: Lieut.-Gereral Fred. Lance writes to us from Luxor under date of 8atnrday: Yesterday afternoon about ten minutes to six o'olock, and a little time before the sun set behind the Theban hills, I was near the temple of Mut when I saw a brilliant meteor falling in a perpendicular direction. It disappeared behind a clump of palm trees. A gentleman and his daughter saw this meteor from the great pylon of the Temple of Karnak; from that point they state that they saw it burst laterally and disappear. They noticed the brilliancy of the meteor, especially at the time of bursting. As the appearance of a meteor in broad daylight is unusual it would be interesting to know whether the phenomenon was observed in other parts of Egypt.

div.head: Sudan Notes.
div.p: E. Oheid, February 16.

We have had very unseasonable weather here lately. A few days ago we had a very bad dust storm which lasted all day and was most unpleasant. On the 15th, whilst we were at dinner, we had a little rain, which is very unusual here so early in the year. It has been very hot lately.

Major Ravenscroft and his new mufattish Mr. Geeve are up here. They have got a lot of good recruits for the Slavery Repression Department and are busy training them. The former leaves for Cairo in a few days.
Several new buildings are in course of erection and are badly needed.
We have great festivities during the visit of the Bishop of Hereford here, including parties, assault-at-arms, and a football match between the 8th and 12th Battalions at which the Bishop kicked off.

div.head: MISSIONS ON THE UPPER NILE
div.p: The headquarters of the mission to the pagan races of the Upper Nile, which recently received the sanction of Lord Cromer, will not, (the "Tribune" hears), be at Mongalla, which has just been safely reached, but at a point much lower down the river. Thirty years ago the necessity for such a mission was urged by General Gordon. The first tribes to be approached are the Dinkas, a warlike and savage people. Dr. Albert Cook, who arrived from Uganda some weeks in advance of the pioneer bands, found that Mongalla was not the most favourable spot for commencing work. It is interesting to note that the missionaries received help from the Commandant at Fashoda, who sent his steamer to tow the sailing vessel through the sudd.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Ararat arrived at Liverpool last Friday morning.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Khios sailed last Saturday for Manchester with a general cargo, including 7,862 bales cotton and 774 cases eggs.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Congo, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due at Alexandria tomorrow.

div.head:
ABYSSINIANS AND COPTS.
THE DEIR ESSULTAN.
div.p: ABYSSINIANS GAIN THE DAY.
Jerusalem, February 24.

A dispute of long standing between the Abyssinians and Copts, dating as far back as tho middle of last century, regarding the ownership of the convent called 'Deir es Sultan," adjacent to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, for which question the Emperor Menelik has sent of late years two special missions to the Sultar, accompanied with costly and rare presents, has at last been adjusted to the satisfaction of the Abyssinians. His Excellency Rechid Bey, the Governor of Jerusalem, acting under orders from the Sublime Porte, has this day caused a separate entrance to the said convent to be opened with a view of handing over its key to General Machachs, the head of the Abyssinian Mission, who has recently returned from Constantinople.

The Sultan had a short time previously issued an Imperial Irade to the effect that the Copts should be called upon to cede to the Abyssinisns a duplicate key of the old door of the convest in question, but the Coptic Bishop of Jerusalem persisted in declining to carry out the request of the Imperial 'Government or to grant any concession whatsoever. In order to avoid using compulsion, the Governor, who acted throughout with tact and moderation suggested, and the Porte concurred, that instead of a duplicate key being given by the Copts a separate gateway to the convent might be opened from the street for the use of the Abyssinan, who from ancient times have been inhabiting the said monastery. Thus the site becomes now practically the property of both sects.

In former time, the Abyssinians, acoording to hints in eccleaiastical history, had considerable possessions within the Holy City, of which they have been deprived, so that there remained only the convent of "Deir es Sultan" above referred to (in which there are at present about 70 Abyssinian monks and pilgrim) which the Copts have been claiming as their own, alleging that the Abyssinians were admitted therein on sufferance, owing to their being in intercommunion with them. In fact, the Copts have been the masters of the place since the door was under their control, and the inmates were locked in or allowed exit whenever they chose. The Abyssinians, on the other hand, could not prove by documentary evidence that the convent really belonged to them, for, in 1839, at the time of the Egyptian occupation of Syria, it happened that all the Abyssinians in Jerusalem died at plague and their library, containing many valuable manuscripts, was then entirely burnt by Ibrahim Pacha, at the instigation of the Armenians under the pretext of danger of infection, with all the documents which might have served them to recover their property in these better times. At any rate Dr. Gobat, once Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem, in a statement made by him on this question in 1852, wrote: "I have myself seen the library 25 years ago together with such documents, and that all those books and documents were consigned to the flames on the aforesaid occasion is most notorious in Jerusalem."

It will not be without interest to mention in this connection that in 1866, when King Theodorus of Abyssinia detained in captivity within his dominions a number of Englishmen, which culminated in a British expedition against his country, that monarch alleged that his action was a retaliation for the indifference displayed by England to his repeated appeals to the British Government for the recovery of the "Deir-es-Sultan" convent from the Copts, and in consequence of that statement the question of that monastery formed the subject of a special Blue Book, which was laid before Parliament in 1867.

div.head: THE LATE MIDDLEMASS BEY.
div.p: Commander Middlemass Bey, late Chief Inspector of the Egyptian Coast Guard, whose death our London Correspondent announced on Friday, had a good deal of naval service to his credit. He first served in the Active daring the Ashantee War, 1873-74, receiving the Ashantee medal for his services. He was highly commended in despatches and promoted for service in the expedition up the Congo against pirates in 1875. His other services were: Lieut. in the Thalia durirg Egyptian war 1882; employed in transport service (Egyptian Medal Khedive's Bronze Star); appointed Inspector General of the Egyptian Coast Guard service in May, 1B84, and in March, 1885, awarded by the Khedive the rank of Bey, in recognition of his zeal and ability whilst holding that post. While in the Egyptian service he was present at the defeat of the Dervishes outside Suakin by Sir F. Grenfell, K.C.B., (Sirdar), 20th December, 1888; mentioned in despatches; Gemaizah clasp; permitted by the Queen to accept and wear the Insignia of the Order of the Medjidiah of the Third Class, which the Khedive had conferred upon him in recognition of services whilst employed in the service of the Egyptian Government. He was granted the rank of Miralei by the Khedive in Dec., 1892. In April, 1896, he retired on pension from the Egyptian Government Service receiving the personal thanks of H. H. the Khedive for services rendered as Inspector General of Coast Guard, Salt, and Fishery Services, the tobacco revenue alone having been raised from £ 106,000 to £l,000,000 during his term of service. He held the rank of Grand Officer of the Imperial Order of the Medjidieh.

div.head:
HELOUAN.
ATTRACTIONS AND AMUSEMENTS.
div.p: SUCCESSFUL AMATEUR THEATRICALS.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENNT).
Helouan, Friday.

Many are the reasons given for facilitating by rail and road the communications between Cairo and Helonan, and yet all things considered Helonan would lose its chief charms if it were brought into closer touch with the noise and bust of the big city and became merged into a mere suburb. As it stands now its chief joys are to be found in its perfect peace and rest, its glorious air, and the simplicity of life, all of which would become impossible if it ever became merely the annexe to crowded Cairo. From time to time the greater world swarms into it but for the moot part the visitors spend their days in healthy open air pursuits and their nights in health-giving repose, and there are but few who would change their lot for the attractions of the social merry-go round of the hub of Egypt.
Social Gatherings.

Not that one need forswear society altogether in Helonan, for many are the gatherings, race meetings, dances, and entertainments which are provided by and for the more energetic and these are always well attended insomuch that visitors have not the same chance of being satisfied by a plethora of them. The Casino was very full on Thursday evening when an excellent company of amateurs gave a very successful entertainment in aid of the organ fund for the English Church. Theatricals are always a great attraction, and Mrs. Warren, Miss Hobson, and Miss Tottenham did their best for the littte comedietta "Petticoat Perfidy," which was the first item of the programme. One could have wished to see these ladies in some other characters, for they had but little plot and next to no humour. Mrs. Warren made a charming little French maid, and spoke her lines prettily enongh when her voice got used to the stage; but Miss Tottenham's part was uncongenial, nor was Miss Hobson's role a sympathetic one. Mr. Trimen gave a couple of good comic songs, notably a mock passionate love song with its refrain "Mingle your eyebrows with mine, love," which called forth an encore, and Mr. Hans Sawyer, who is an elocutionist of no little merit, gave a very successful and amusing "Engine driver's story" with local allusions.
Mrs. Jarley's Waxworks.

The second half of the evening's entertainment was given over to the performance of Mrs. Jarley's Waxworks, that celebrated showwoman being impersonated by Mr. Madden, while Mr. Hans Sawyer made a most praiseworthy George. The vargaries of the "waxworks" and their mechanical irresponsibilities and breakdowns were very cleverly rendered, and the witticisms of Mrs. Jarley and George were at times exceedingly to the point. Much praise is due to the figure for their actions and utterances, Miss Tottenham being especially clever in her wooden movements and incontrollable actions. Mr. Charlesworth played his part of a very "SimpleSimon" and Mr. Lord made an excellent "Fat Joe." "Mary and her lamb," and "Bopeep" never looked prettier than when enacted by Visa L Zahotkine and Miss Bentley respectively, and Miss Babbington Jones' voice as "Signs Squallina" will not easily be forgotten. Mr. Ford made many great hits as a "Professional Golfer," and Miss Zabotkine as the "Baby on the Shore" had the sympathy of the entire house when she was brought to bay under an empty crate at the termination of the proceedings. It is estimated that about £50 has been made by the entertainment, and if so it will not be long before the church is in possession of the organ it so badly requires.
Race Meeting.

The race meeting today brought together the usual number of people and proved a thoroughly enjoyable afternoon but for the unfortunate mishap that caused Mr. Michaeli does a nasty spill during the last race. He had been more than usually lucky during the earlier afternoon and most people would have been glad to see him score another win. Among those noticed in the enclosure were Mr. and Mrs. Satow, the Misses Hurley, Miss Fullerton, Mrs. Smart, Mrs. Freeman, Dr. Graf, Mr. Payne, Miss Wait, the Hon. F. Morgan, Mr. Draper, Mr. Reid, Mr. and Mrs. Phillips, Mr. Doherty, Mrs. Shepperd, Capt. and Miss Morgan, Mr. and Mrs. Huteson, Mrs. and the Misses Bentley, Major Watson, Mrs. Warren, Major and Mrs. Wynne, Capt. Outram, Miss Darley, Miss Duncan, Mr. Lord, Mrs. Hopkinson, Mr. Carter-Wilson, Col. Sparkes, Aziz Pacha Izzat, Ahmed Bey Bakri, and Mrs. and the Misses Zabotkine.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lady Cromer and her sister, Lady Beatrice Thynne, her son, the Hon. Evelyn Baring, and suite have returned to Cairo from Mena House, where the air has done the young child a deal of good, the weather being at its best now at Mena.
Three birthdays of prominent Anglo-Egyptians feel last week. Lord Cromer was born on the Feb. 26, 1841, Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield on March 3, 1835, and Judge Marshall on the same day in 1864.

Mr. and Mrs. Brodrick and Miss Sybil Brodrick after their visit to Egypt will probably go to India. About a year ago it seemed possible that Mr. Brodrick would go to India under very different circumstances. Unless rumour was quite wrong, Mr. Baltour was on the point of recommending the appointment of Mr. Brodrick to be Lord Curson's successor as Viceroy of India. It such was his intention it came to nought, for the cabled rumour roused such opposition in India, as well as at home that Mr. Brodrick's chance was gone.

Mr. Anderson Fowler, one of the pioneers in the packing industry and for many years the president of the Anglo-American Packing & Provision Company, has died while touring Egpyt. Two other members of the Fowler family died from diseases contracted in Egpyt, Robert E. Fowler and the Rev. James W. Fowler, brothers of Andesen Fowler, being poisoned by the drinking water.

Mr. Fowler leaves an estate estimated at $15,000,000 to be distributed among the widow and nine children. The property consists of large holdings of timber lands in the South and West. Mr. Fowler was in the packing business for more than 30 years. In 1902, he sold out to the National Packing Company. Mr. Fowler was 53 years old. For the last 15 years he had lived in New York.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe last night: Messrs. E. Tanket and C. T. Battie, Misses Borwich, Mr. Borwich, Mr. Pelizaeus, Mr. Manson, Comtesse Grother, Mr. Wolff, Mr. Bock, Mr. Vendscher, Mr. Barthes, Cook's Moltke party of 7.

div.head: RETURN OF H.M.S. DONEGAL.
div.p: H. M.'s first-class cruiser Donegal, which was ashore at Tor Bank, in the Suez Gulf, was refloated, as I informed you by wire, last Friday evening, and as she sustained very slight damage she apparantly must have proceeded. She is bound for China and will call at Aden, Colombo, and Shanghai.
The British homeward-bound steamer Ratho has been ashore in the Canal, between 152 Kilo. station and Port Tewfik, since early this morning and is blocking the way. All traffic is stopped.
The Khedivial mail liner Rahmanieh arrived at Suez yesterday from Tor with a large number of Egpytian pilgrims, who are the first to return. The health of the pilgrims is good.
Suez, Later.
The S.S. Ratho has been refloated this afternoon with the assistance of the Canal Company's tug Titan.
Suez, Monday.
H.M.S. Donegal has returned to Suez this morning.

div.head:
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
FINAL STAGE REACHED.
AN APPEAL FOR CONCILIATION.

div.p: An authoritative statement appears which indicates that a compromise is probable at Algeciras. (Reuter)

The Conference has adopted a Bank scheme drafted by, a committee, being a sort of compromise between the French and German-Morocco schemes but incomplete on several important points, which will be revised at a farther discussion.

Sir A. Nicolson proposed that the Conference, should consider the police question in committee on Monday while the Bank scheme is officially before the Conference. Germany, Austria, and Morocco voted against this proposal. (Reuter)
The Conference has passed several clauses of the Bank project and reserved others. (H.)

The Conference has agreed to Sir A. Nicolson's proposal mentioned yesterday evening. It appears that the Conference has reached its final stage when a solution will become imperative. Signor Visconti-Venosta eloquently appealed for conciliation. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE KING IN PARIS
DINNER AT BRITISH EMBASSY.

div.p: The King embarked on board the Royal yacht yesterday evening en route for Cherbourg. His Majesty looked extremely well. He travels incognito and will meet M. Fallieres and M. Ronvier at a dinner at the British Embassy in Paris tomorrow. (Reuter)
The King of England has arrived. (Havas)

King Edward paid a visit to M. Fallieres in the afternoon. The interview was vary cordial. The people cheered the King. In the evening a dinner was given at the British Embassy. M. Faallieres and M. Ronvier with their wives were present. (Havas)

div.head:
KAIRSER TO VISIT SPAIN.
PROBABLY ATTEND OLYMPIC GAMES.

div.p: The Emperor will visit Spain in April. His Majesty will probably go to Greece for the Olympic games. He may meet King Edward in the Mediterranean. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SPANISH MARRIAGE.
PRINCESS ENA'S CONVERSION.

div.p: Mr. Gladstone refused to receive a deputation from the Protestant Alliance on the subject of Princess Ena's marriage. (Reuter)

It is reported that King Edward, King Alfonso, Queen Christine, and the Prince and Princess of Battenberg will meet on Wednesday at San Sebastiano where the Bishop of Sion will receive Princess Ena into the Catholic Church. (Reuter)
Sir Edward Clarke, speaking here, said that the Unionists will never regain their influence till they have repudiated absolutely the proposals regarding the tax on corn and meat. (Reuter)

Frequent cases show that the Russian revolutionaries are attacking in broad daylight the mail coaches of the post-offices and banks threatening the officials with revolvers and carrying off the money. Similar outrages have taken place recently at Kieff and Riga. (R.)

div.head:
THE SEVASTOPOL MUTINY.
SENTENCE ON PRISONERS.

div.p: Lieutenant Schmidt has been sentenced to be hanged, and 30 sailors to be shot or to undergo various terms of imprisonment, in connection with the Sevastopol mutiny. (R.)
Four officers of the Orchakoff, who mutinied, have been condemned to death and some others to hard labour. (Havas)

A disastrous tornado took place in the Society Islands (Pacific Ocean) on the 7th February. The whole of the settlements have been destroyed and the inhabitants are starving. The damage is enormous and the mortality immense. (Reuter)
A tornado has wrecked Meridian (Miss.). 21 whites and over one hundred negroes have been killed. (Reuter)
The Marquis Romero Robledo is dead. (R.)
Association Wales beat Scotland by 2 to nil. (Reuter)

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de gargouilles de pour trottoirs aveo accessoires.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 40.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 3 Avril prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fourniture de gargouilles pour trottoirs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 3 Avril prochain a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 27 Fevrier 1906.

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire.
div.p: AVIS
Il est porte a la connaissance du public que le Conseil d'Administration de la Societe a decide de reduire de 22% le prix de l'ean fournie anx Bornes fontaines publiques.
Eu consequence, a partir du ler Janvier 1906 on pourra obtenir l'eau aux dites tontai nes a raison de P.T. 3 (trois piastres tarif) le metre cube au lien de P.T. 3,857 payees jusqu'ici.

Cette reduction de prix ayant ete decidee par la Societe dans le soul but d'en faire profiter les habitants de la Ville, le public est prie de veiller a ce que la dite reduction lui soit faite par les sakas qui lui fournissent l'eau, afin de ne pas laisser ces derniers profiter du rabais qui n'a ete consenti qu'en faveur du public.
La vente d'eau au detail aux Bornes fontaines, s'etablit donc comme suit :
Le tonneau de 660 kilos de jauge 20 millieme
Le guerbe de 66 kilos de jauge 2 millieme
L'estagnon de 22 kilos de jauge 3/4 millieme
et pour toute quantite depassant la jauge cidessus chaque 4 kilos seront comptes a 1/8 de milliemes.
Le Caire, le 19 Decembre 1905. Le Directeur
26974-30A-26 ASTLEY P. FRIEND.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: La Societe Anonyme The Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company a ete fondee le 26 Novembre 1904 an Capital de £160,000 divise en 16,000 setioins de L.E. 10 nominal entierement liberees.

Aux termes de ses statuts elle a pour objet l'etude, la preparation et l'execution pour son compte on pour compte de tiers on eu participation de toutes operations en terrains et immeubles urbains on ruraux, de construction de canaux, reservoirs, digues, drains, chemins de fer, tramways, d'entreprises d'irrigation et generalement de tons travaux d'amelioration ainsi que de toutes entreprises industrielles se rattachant a l'agriculture.

Depuis la fondation de la Societe, les affaires ont immediatement pris un developpement tel que non seulement le capital original a ete juge insufficant, mais que meme l'augmentation de capital de L.E. 40,000 prevue par les statuts n'aurait pas permis d'etendre suffisamment les affaires de la Societe.

Une assemblee generale extraordinaire des actionnaries tenue au Caire le 15 Decembre 1905 a approuve a l'unanimite la proposition du Conseil de porter le capital a £400,000 par l'emission de 24,000 Actions Nonvelles du meme type que les actions anciennes et participant aux benefices sociaux a prtir du 1 Janvier 1906.

Cette augmentation de capital a ete prise ferme par un groupe de financiers belges dirige par le Banque de Reports de Fonds Publics et de Depots a Auvers, et la Societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce au Caire.
Sur ces 24,000 actions nouvelles, il en a ete souscrit 13,000 par les anciens actionnaires en vertu d'un droit de preference qui leur a ete reserve.
Le solde soit 11,000 actions fait l'objet de la presents emission et est offert eu public au prix de L.E. 12 par action.

Le situation de la Societe telle qu'elle a ete exposes a l'Assembles generale ordinaire tenue le 20 Janvier dernier est des plus satisfaisantes. Les benefices realises dans le courant du premier exercise out permis la distribution d'un divideude de 8 1/2% aux actions de capital et P.T. 35 aux parts de dividende.

L'exercice en cours se presente des maintenant sous un aspects des plus favorables. Un lot de terrain acquis l'an dernier vient d'etre realise aveo un benefice d'environ L.E. 23,000 et des offres fermes out ete faites a la Societe pour divers autres terrains a des prix qui laisseraient un benefice immediat de plus de L.E. 40,000.
Certaines affaires en participation out acquis une telle plus value que leur realisation immediate assurerait un benefice considerable.

Ces que'ques considerations suffiront amplement pour demontrer que des maintenant la Societe a non saulement trouve un emploi remunerateur pour son noveau capital, mais que l'on peut esperer que les benefices du present exercise suffiront largement pour distribuer sur l'ensemble du capital de L.E. 40,000 des dividendes au moins equivalents a ceux de l'an dernier.
27404-5-3 LE CONSEIL D'ADMINISTRATION.

div.head: CAIRO POLO TOURNAMENT.
div.p: Two more ties in the Polo Cup were played off on Friday afternoon before a fair number of spectators. Taking it on the whole the polo was not good, though, Dalby, for the 60th., and Bartlett, for the Mosquitoes, played brilliantly.
1ST CHUKKER.

The Mosquitoes were first on the ball Graham running the ball to the 60th goal where Dalby returned, and getting on to the ball made a good run down the far side of the ground, centering beautifully in front of goal, but Bartlett cleared and brought the ball round and hit well up to his forwards. Dudgeon had a fairly easy shot but hit wide - a good chance missed. Up-and-down play followed in which Bartlett and Dalby were conspicuous. Seymour twice hit behind. From the hit-out Graham brought the ball up the ground but Dalby returned and Seymour again hit behind. Result - no scoring. Quite a good chukker, the ball travelling up and down at a good pace.
2ND CHUKKER.

Give and take play followed the hit out till the 60th ran the ball to the Mosquitoes' goal, when Dalby missed a "sitter" a yard or two from goal. For some reason Bartlett hit out across his goal and both he and Dudgeon missing in turn Pardoe hit a good goal. From the throw-in the Mosquitoes attacked strongly and Bartlett though being ridden should have hit a goal. Graham then got clean away, but missing, Dalby returned. The Mosquitoes again attacked but hit wde behind. The ball was then brought to the Mosquitoes' goal, where Stockwell getting hold made a most brilliant run the whole length of the ground, hitting a goal. Result - 60th, 1 goal; Mosquitoes, 1 goal. This was an excellent chukker and very fast, first one side attacking then the other.
3RD CHUKKER.

From the throw-in Stockwell hit the ball up and Dalby returned. Dalby then got away and brought off a good run but his final shot went wide. From the hit-out Bartlett brought the ball up the ground and Graham riding Dalby well a goal seemed certain, bat Bartlett nissed and Seymour returned. Up-and-down play followed in which Stockwell, Bartlett, and Dalby were conspicuous. Dalby thun made a brilliant run down the far side and cutting well into the centre followed up and scored a goal from a difficult angle. 60th, 2 goals; Mosquitoes, 1 goal.
4th CHUKKER.

Stockwell got away and centered well, giving Bartlett a difficult near side shot at goal which he failed to bring off. Again the Mosquitoes got a chance without result. First Dalby and then Stockwell made good runs and Graham getting offside spoilt a good chance on his side. Eustace then fouled Bartlett, and from the penalty hit Bartlett ran the ball down but hit wide. Again the Mosquitoes attacked and Graham with a good run almost scored. 60th, 2 goals; Mosquitoes, 1.

On the day's play the Mosquitoes were unlucky to lose, as they oertainly had more of the game and played better together, but they failed to take advantage of their chances. Bartlett again played brilliantly. Stockwell also played very well and made a couple of brilliant runs. Graham hit well at times, but his ponies were a bit out of hand.

For the winners Dalby played most brilliantly and did most of the work on his side. If it had not been for him they would have had a big score against them. Pardoe stuck to his back well, but the other two were not at their best.
1ST CHUKKER

The E.A were first on the ball, but Dunbar getting hold with a good run nearly scored the hall going behind. Some scrummaging in front of goal followed the hit-out and Protherce Smith hit a goal. From the throw-in the Freebootors ran the ball down and Brakenridge returned well but Protherce Smith meeting the ball nearly scored. From the hit-out Kennedy centered well to Dunbar, who had a good chance of scoring but hit wide. The E.A. were pressed for the first time but failed to take advantage of a good chance. Protherce Smith got on at midfield and with two good hits nearly scored. Results - Freebooters, 2 goals ; E.A. nil. A good chukker in which the Freebooters did all the pressing.
2ND CHUKKER

From the hit-out Rome took the ball down the ground, but Rumbold returned and Dunbar slipping the back got away, but the ball bumped and Rome returned. Give-and-take play followed till Rome, getting on, took the ball down the ground and centering well a melee took place in front of goal from which the E.A. got a goal. Up-and-down play followed, first one side attacking then the other. Rome hit up well and following up nearly scored from a fine shot, the ball not quite reaching the goal. The E.A. again attacked and Dunbar just managed to save the ball going behind Freebooters, 2 goals ; E.A 1. The E.A. showed improved form; a good galloping chukker.
3RD CHUKKER

Good up-and-down play followed the hit out Brakenridge missed, giving Dunbar an easy shot at goal, from which he scored. The E.A. now attacked but hit behind. Some rather sticky polo followed till Dunbar hitting well nearly cored with a good shot. Rome brought the ball down from the hit-out. Rumbold returning again, the E.A. worked the ball down the ground and Rome had a chance at a difficult angle but hit wide. Shortly afterwards they again hit behind Dunbar then made a good run right up the ground but missed his last shot. From the hit-out Kennedy hit a subsi diary. Freebooters, 3 goals, 1 sub; E.A., 1 goal.
4TH CHUKKER

A bad hit-out allowed Kennedy to hit a goal. From the throw-in Protherce Smith hit well, but Brakenridge returned with a fine backhander and Cox made a good run on the far side of the ground, the ball going behind. The E.A. again pressed but Dunbar saved well, bringing the ball round with two good near side shots, the ball going out. Dunbar shortly afterwards had another shot at goal but hit wide. From the hit-out Brakenridge made a good run but the ball went over the boards. From some scrambling play in midfield Dunbar came through well and all but scored, Protherce Smith hitting a subsidiary. Result - Freebooters, 4 goals 2 subs.; E.A. 1 goal. This was not a very good game, the play being rather of the scrambling order. On the day's play, the Freebooters were a good bit the stronger, showing better combination and being quicker on the ball. For the winners, Dunbar played well though I have seen him hit better. Rumbold was safe and did all that was asked of him and Protherce Smith at times hit well. For the losers Rome and Brakenridge played best, the latter's backhanders being particularly clean and strong.

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: KHEDIVIEH v. TEWFIKIEH SCHOOLS.

"Enthusiast" (Cairo) writes: - In case of your Cairo Correspondant not sending yon an account of today's great match, I am writing you a brief account of it, hoping you will be kind as to give it a corner in your paper. The match being by far the most important of its kind in Egypt in fact it is the 'Varsity match of Egypt - it would be deemed rather disappointing to we Egyptians should it go unnoticed. It was the second of the inter-school matches, played this time on the Khedivieh School ground of Helmieh, the previous one being played on Dec. 28th 1905 at Shubra when the Tewfikieh School was beaten by two goals to one, after a hard game. The kickoff took place at 3:30 p.m. sharp. The Tewfikieh boys winning the toss, played with the sun behind them. From the start it was clearly seen that the Khed. boys possessed far better combination than their rivals. Ten minutes from the start, after a brilliant piece of combination, the Khed. left wing Mahmoud Ali sent the ball flying into the opponents net and thus scored the first point for his school. Even after that the home team kept their opponents penned up in their own quarters for the remainder of the first half. But the brilliancy of one of the Tewfikieh backs called Osman Hafez was of no avail, for the Khed. centre forward called Ahmed Aly emplated the example of his brother and added another point to the credit of his school. The second half was of a very even nature although the visiting team appeared to be dangerous at times. But the Khed. backs were able to acquit themselves no less prominently than their visitors the capt. of the Khed here - Bahgat El Shurbagy well fufilling his function. During this half neither team scored though the Tewfikieh boys played a plucky game and proved that they had far improved than on the previous occasion. Thus this interesting game ended in a victory for the home team by 2 goals to love, this being the sixth consecutive match in which the Khedivieh School have been the victors.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 3 mars.

A Londres, le Consolide anglais a regagne hier 1/8 a 90 3/8. L'Unifiee est restee invariee a 105 1/4 et la National Bank a 27 3/8. La Daira Sanieh est en nouvelle hausse de 1/8 a 18. Par contre, l'Agricole est renseignee on reaction de 1/8 a 9 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptian a c'oture a 792, soit en baisse de 4 francs. La Banque a'Athenes a encore gague 1 franc a 147.
Notre marche des valeurs a ete, ce matin encore, tres calme sur le groupe des Barques. Eu revanche, il s'est montre fort anime sur quelques petites valeurs et divers autres titres.
La National Bank et l'Agricole sont restees a leurs cours d'hier, sans affaires. La Barque d'Athenes a c'oture a 142 ex-coupon.
L'action Credit Foncier est revenue a 792 ; l'obligation a lots 1886 a avance a 338; les nonvelles se maintiennent a 276. La Daira Sanieh a flechi a 17 15/16.
L'Immobiliere a encore progresse a 377 ; l'Agricole du Nil a 274; la part de dividende a atteint 7 3/4 pour cloturer a 7 1/2.
La part de fondateur Enterprise and Development a avance a 14 5/8 et l'action a 12 1/2.
L'action d'Enterprises Immobilieree et de Travaux est traitee an pair; la part de fondateur est tres recherchee a L.E. 7 3/4.
Sur la nouve'le de la declaration de faillite, les Sucreries ont baisse de 26 a 20 pour remonter a 24 et cloturer a 22.
Dans le groupe de Horels, les Nungovich ont ete cotes entre 14 et 14 1/16 et les Baehler a 5 1/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, bon mouvement sur les Delta Land et les Hooker, qui ont cloture plus ou moins a leurs prix d'hier. La part de fondateur Estates a gagne une 1/2 livre a 9. Nombreuses transactions sur les Egyptian Constructions, qui ont ouvert a 1 5/8 pour c'oturer a 1 1/2. Les Walker and Meimarachi sont revenus a 0 13/16.
Contrairement a ce qu'affirme un journal d'Alexandrie nous sommes en mesure de declarer que la fusion de la Delta Land avec l'Egyptian Land and General Trust est un fait accompli.
Le fusion a ete signee par les repre entants des deux Conseils d'administration et sera soumise prochainement aux assemblees des deux Societes.

On rapporte que l'Egpytian Estates Co. est sur le point de conclure une affaire importante en terrains de culture. La Societe avait achete recemment environ 3,000 feddans a £11 le feddan, pour lesquels on lui affrirait actuellement le prix de £18. Si l'affaire aboutit, la Societe tirera de cette transaction un profit de £21,000.
M. Beckett, directeur general de la Corporation of Western Egypt (Oasis), est revenu de Londres, avec un ingenieur experiuente qui prendra la direction des travaux du chemin de fer de la Societe.
Trois locomotives et autre material roulant sont attendus d'Augleterre vers le 20 du courant.
Nous detachons d'une de nos lettres d'Alexandrie les lignes suivantes.

"On estime ici que les efforts faits pour creer un deconvert sur les Egyptian Constructions out pleinment reussi. La tache etsit, d'ailleurs aisee. En effet, beancoup de souscripteurs, courant apres le benefice de la prime, ont vendu par 500 et par 1000, comptant qu'il leur serait alloue le 7% (la souscription ayant ete, dit on, couverte 15 fois) et ce avant d'etre fixes sur la question de savoir comme le repartition serait exactement faite. Ils out ainsi forme eux memes un decouvert considerable qui aura pour effet de pousser peut etre encore plus haut le cours du titre. Reste a voir a quel prix ces souscriptures devront se couvrir pour la quantite qu'ils ont vendue sans se l'etre d'abord assuree."

Le Tribunal mix'e du Caire a rendu ce matin son jugement dans l'affaire des Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte. L'intervention des creanciers est recue, la demande a'homologation rej tee et la faillite declaree. Le jugement fait remonter la cessation des paiements a la date fixee dans le premier rapport des experts. M. Sanpaolo est nomme syndic.
Les cours du coton arrivent en hausse d'Ame rique. Hier, le disponible a rattrape 10 points, le mai 14 et l'Octobre 8.
Les arrivages ont ete de 24,000 balles contre 20,000.
Le marche de Liverpool est egalement en reprise.
Ici, le Mars qui avait fini hier soir a 18 29/32 a ouvert ce matin a 19 3/8 pour c'oturer au meme prix.

MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l'execution de tous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marches de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et New York. La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyee sur demande.

div.head: EGPYTIAN ENTERPRISE AND DEVELOPMENT
div.p: Comme nous l'avions annonce dans notre numero de Samedi, c'est ce matin qu'a ete ouverte au Caire a l'Auglo Egyptian Bank et a Societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce la soucription publique a 11,000 actions de l'Egyptian Enterprise and Development.
Nous avons sous les yeux le bilan que cette Societe a publie a la cloture de son premier exercice.

Les proprietes de la Societe se divisent en deux categories: les terrains de culture et les terrains a batir. La premiere categorie comprend deux proprietes, l'une de 2,102 feddans a Dakahlah, province de Dakahlieh, l'autre de 1,992 feddans aux villages de Mansourieh et Bercache, province de Ghizeh.

Ces deux domaines ne sont cultives qu'en partie et sont encore dans la periode d'amelioration. Les travaux de nivellement, canalisation etc. a Dakahla geront termines cette annee, et, l'irrigation et le drainage etant assures a la suite de ces travaux, cette propriete entrerades l'annea courante dans la classe des terrains en pleine culture. Elle a deja acquis actuellement une plus value importante.

Quant aux terrains a batir, tous sont situes au Caire; ils valent des a present sensiblement plus que les sommes portees au bilan, et meme l'un des lots vient d'etre realise avec un benefice de L.E. 20,000.

div.head: SOCIETE KHEDIVIALE DE GEOGRAPHIE
div.p: La conference donnee par M. R. Golrat, charge de missions par le Gouvernement francais, a eu un succes oratoire indiscutable, car M. Colrat parle avec le force et la conviction, qui sont les deux qualites essentielles de l'eloquence. Quant au fond, trop empreint peut-etre de chauvinisme pour un public international, les details qu'il neus a donne sur l'oeuvre du Gouvernement francais en Tunisie, sont du plus haut interet. Il a passe en revue ce qu'on a tait dans l'administration, la justice, l'instruction, les travaux publics, l'agriculture et ce qu'on va faire encore a la suite des plus grands pouvoirs confies au Resident general. C'est un tableau qui fait beaucoup d'honneur au gouvernment francais sans doute, mais l'orateur a glisse sur la part que les francais eux-memes comme emigrants out apportee a ces succes. Chacun sait qu'en Tuuisre on se plaint que les francais, colons, agriculteurs, industriels y diminuent chaque jour au lieu d'augmenter.

La premiere partie de la conference a ete consacree a l'expose des caracteres de la colunisation chez les divers peuples et l'orateur, naturellement, a prone, comme superieur a tous les autrel le systeme francais, qui vise a son avis, uniquement a la liberte et au bonheur du peuple soumis ou annexe.
Des applaudissements chaleureux ont interrompu plusieurs fois l'orateur, qui a la fin a ete salue par une vertiable ovation.

div.head: PAUL KOCHANSKI
div.p: Le concert donne samedi soir, par le celebre violoniste polonais Paul Kochanski, a ete pour notre ville un des evenements artistiques les plus eclatants de la saison. La salle du New Khedivial Hotel etsit trop petite pour contenir la foule qui a'y pressait afin d'entendre un des plus admirables virtuoses de notre epoque.

Bien qu'il ne soit age que de 15 ans a peine, P. Kochanski ne connsit deja plus de difficultes pour son instrument, dont l'etude-est pourtant indefinie. Il semble qu'il ait atteint les limites extremes du savoir et de l'execution.
Nous avouons pour notre part n'avoir jamais entendu un archet aussi doux, aussi adroit et aussi leste.
L'interpretation des divers morceaux qui figuraient au programme a ete superieure.
A la fin du concert P. Kochanski a ete l'objet d'une ovation enthousiaste.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hiu a midi et demie)

L'entrain a ete admirable ce matin. Les transactions ont porte specialement sur les petites valeurs, Investment, Trust, Estates, et Salt & Soda. Parmi les gros titres l'Agricole et les Nungovich ont ete l'objet d'une forte demande.
Les Egpytian Constructions avaient flechi dans la matinee a 1 3/8, mais elles ony ensuits repris a 1 1/2.
La hausse est particulierement sensible pour l'Agricole qui atteint 10 3/16, la Cassa di Sconto 205 les Nungovich 14 9/16 et la Khedivial Mail Ordinary 4 1/6.
Par contre, les Sucreries tombent a 16 francs.
L'Urbaine se reveille a 5 9/16 la Ramleh Railway a 6 13/16, les Tramways d'Alexandrie a 165 1/4.
Ce mouvement cadre exactement avec nos previsions de samedi dernier. Il est appele a s'sooentuer fortement si les nonvelles politiques conservent leur ton optimiste.
The Alexandria Central Bullding Co. vient de reussir a Londres le p'acement de £100,000 d'obligations a 4% remboursables au gre de la societe, moyennant un preavis d'un mois seulement.

div.head: DESIGNATION DES IMMEUBLES
div.p: 1er LOT

Ouest terrains de Call Rak, Sud terrains du Gouvernement a Soufia, Est terrains de Ahmed Fahmy et ses freres enfants de feu Saleh bey Amin actuellement Dr. Fares Eff. Nimr, Nord terrains ci apres designes sis a El Kassasin.

Huit kirats par indivis sur vingt quatre kirats dans: 349 feddans, 18 kirats et 16 sahmes sis au village de Kassassin El Sebakh (Ch.) au hod Bahr El Aggour divises et limites comme suit:

Cette vente ese poursuivie a la requete du Sieur Aristidi Polimeri, proprietaire hellene demeurant a Abou Kebir et elisant domicile a Mansourah dans le Cabinet de Me Paul Bard, avocat a la Cour.
Contre, Le Sr. Zayad Amer Badran, proprietaire sujet local demeurant a Awlad Moussa (Charkieh).
En vertu,

1. d'un jugement du Tribunal de Commerce de Mansourah en date du 26 Mai 1904 rendu au profit du poursuivant contre le Sr. Zayad Amer Badran auquel jugement il a ete acquiesce par le dit Sr. Badran le 19 Juillet 1904.

2. D'un exploit de l'huissier ft. N. Foti en date du 11 Avril 1905 par lequel le requerant a fait signifier au Sr. Zayad Amer Badran le dit jugement portant son a quisescement avec un commandement de paisement; la dit commandement transcrit au bureau des hypotheques du Tribunal Mixte de Mansourah en date du 17 Avril 1905 sub. No. 18084.

3. D'un proces-verbal de l'huissier Dendia en date du 7 Juin 1905 par lequel il a ete procede en vertu du dit jugement a la saisie des immeubles sus-designes; lequel proces-verbal portant denonciation au debiteur saisi, a ete transcrit au bureau des hypotheques de Mansourah le 21 Juin 1905 sub. No. 23828)
4. D'un jugement rendu par la Chambre Civile du Tribunal Mixte de Mansourah en date du 22 Pavrier 1906 ordonnant le lotissement des dits immeubles tel qu'il a ete decrit ci-haut.
Pour Obtenir Paiement.
1. de la somme principale de P.T. 38331 1/2 plus les interets a 9 0/0 l'an a partir du 1er Decembre 1904 et les frais judiciaries suivant taxe.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These express steamer's have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
